sect1.title: Authority, Duties and Responsibilities of a Commander
sect1.para: The commander has overall responsibility for the safety of the aircraft, its occupants and its cargo, and the authority to issue any commands required to secure this. He has the authority to increase any safety margin, including aerodrome operating minima, as he sees fit. In an emergency situation, he has the authority to override any rule or procedure in the interest of safety.

He must ensure that:
All SOPS are fully complied with.
The weather will not infringe operating minima and the required alternates are available.
Ground facilities and services required for the planned flight are available and adequate.
The correct types and quantities of fuel and oil are carried, and uplifts are recorded.
The aircraft and required equipment are serviceable or only have unserviceabilities that comply with the CDL or MEL. If third party maintenance is required whilst away from base, the procedures referred to in 8.1.11, Aircraft Technical Log, must be followed.
The preflight inspection has been completed, and that all required documents, maps and charts are onboard and valid.
The aircraft is within its weight and balance envelope and the load is properly secured.
The available aircraft performance is sufficient for all phases of the proposed flight.
Any person, or any part of the cargo, which may represent a potential hazard to the safety of the aircraft or its occupants is disembarked. This includes:
Persons under the influence of alcohol or drugs, to the extent that they pose a risk. Inadmissible passengers, deportees or persons in custody if they pose any risk.
A full safety briefing, including exits and equipment carried, is given to the passengers.
Crew members are not permitted to perform any activity during take-off, initial climb, final approach and landing except those duties required for the safe operation of the aircraft.
A continuous listening watch is maintained on the appropriate radio frequencies.
The cabin is secured (passengers secured and cabin baggage properly stowed) for taxi, take-off, landing and whenever turbulence is expected.
The cabin crew are secured in their allocated seats for takeoff, landing and when not carrying out essential duties whilst taxiing.
The flight data recorder is not disabled, switched off or erased during flight nor erased after flight in the event of an accident or an incident subject to mandatory reporting.
The flight deck door is locked at all times between engine start and engine shutdown, with the exception of when it must be opened for physiological reasons.
A post flight debrief is carried out.
A journey log or equivalent ACARS is completed.

sect2.title: Flight crew
sect2.para: The minimum flight crew is two pilots, at least one of whom must be a Captain.
The commander must sit in the left seat unless the commander is a training Captain and is required to occupy the right seat for a training detail.
A training Captain may carry out both PNF and PF roles from either seat. Other Captains may only carry out the PNF role from the right seat.

If an aircraft is only being taxied, the occupant of the right seat may be a non-type rated pilot or a suitably qualified ground employee. The occupant of the left seat must, however, be a fully type qualified commander.

Inexperienced (***) crew must not operate together. A Captain is considered inexperienced until he has successfully passed his first recurrent simulator check. A First Officer is considered inexperienced until he has completed the amount of flying detailed in EOM/A section 4.1.2.

sect2.title: Cabin crew
sect2.para:
The minimum cabin crew is normally one for every 50 installed seats. In extreme circumstances this may be reduced by one cabin crew member providing that:
Authorisation is received from the duty pilot
The aircraft does not dispatch from its originating base.
The applicable sectors are either part of the original series of flights or are associated diversions.
A maximum of 50 passengers (not including infants) per cabin crew member is carried.
All passengers are seated in a position where they can adequately view the safety demonstration.
If the reduction in cabin crew results in no SCCM being carried there are additional procedures detailed in EOM/A-4.1.4g.

It is permissible to board with one cabin crew member absent provided that:
The operating SCCM is present.
A member of the flight crew is on the flight deck. In case of emergency a member of flight crew will assist at the front of the cabin.
The front and rear doors each have at least one attendant cabin crew member.
The aircraft is not being fuelled.
A maximum of 50 passengers per cabin crew member are boarded.

It is also permissable to board with a non operating crew member provided that they are fully qualified on type, in uniform and fit to operate. They are not required to have taken part in the pre-flight brief, but must be briefed on their duties during boarding and must have answered one SEP and one First Aid question. The non operating crew member must remain with the aircraft until the rostered crew member arrives.
During disembarkation, once there are less than 20 passengers remaining on board the required crew complement is reduced to the SCCM and one member of flight crew.

If a cabin crew member is incapacitated due to sickness, injury, tiredness or fatigue, they must be offloaded. They will then be considered unfit to fly until certified fit by a doctor or paramedic. This rule may be overridden at the Captain's discretion if "extraordinary circumstances" apply.

sect2.title: Positioning crew
sect2.para: EOM/A-4.5; EOM/A-4.6

Positioning crew will normally be booked as passengers and procede through normal passenger channels. When arriving on a domestic flight it is permissable for crew to transfer aircraft on the ramp, but if arriving on an international flight crew must clear immigration and customs before proceding to the aircraft via security search.
In exceptional circumstances staff may be carried as "extra crew". This requires the authorisation of the duty pilot or the Network Duty Manager. In this case, crew must be shown on the crew list.

sect2.title: Flight Ops Inspectors
sect2.para: EOM/A-4.7
Flight Ops Inspectors may, at any time, board any easyJet aircraft and enter and remain on the flight deck unless it is the commander's opinion that this would endanger the safety of the aircraft.
Flight Ops Inspectors may act as operating crew with the approval of the duty pilot, but may only fly with a training Captain.

sect1.para:
[EOM/A-5] The minimum qualifications to act as a commander are:
A UK JAA-FCL ATPL with relevant type rating
Class I medical
Valid ATQP recurrent checks:
Test/ TrainingValidity
Licence Proficiency Check
Incorporates Operator Proficiency Check, Instrument Rating renewal, and elements of Ground and Refresher Training. 12 months
The period of validity starts on the last day of the month in which the training and/or test was completed.
For renewals, the period of validity can start on the expiry date of the current check. To be considered a renewal, the training and/or test must be completed a maximum of three months before that expiry date.
Line Oriented Evaluation

Line check 24 months
Dangerous Goods 24 months less 1 day
Aviation Security 12 months

Triennial Emergency and Safety Equipment Check 3 years
Three take-offs and three landings as PF in the preceding 90 days.
For Cat III, two landings, possibly in a simulator, using Cat III procedures within 12 months. This requirement is usually satisfied by the LPC.
3000 factored hours of which 500 hours must be on a medium or large jet transport (see EOM/A-5.2.1 for factored hours table).
Successful completion of a Command Course.

sect2.title: Alcohol
sect2.para: Do not consume any alcohol within 10 hours of a duty, and consume no more that 5 units of alcohol within 24 hours of a duty.
Crews are obliged to comply with random breathalysing, but should ensure that it is not carried out in front of passengers.
Alcohol must never be consumed whilst in uniform in a public place.
Alcohol must not be taken onto the flight deck during flight.

sect2.title: Cosmic radiation
sect2.para: Statutory directives state that the acceptable radiation exposure of aircrew is 6mSv/yr. Radiation exposure is modelled by easyJet to try to prevent exposure above this level. At easyJet's operating latitudes, 1mSv exposure is equivalent to 200 hours at 35000 feet.
Embryos and foetuses are particularly susceptible to harm from cosmic radiation. Crew should not fly when pregnant.

sect2.title: Medication
sect2.para: The use of non-prescribed narcotics or sleep inducing drugs is forbidden.
Do not operate within 48 hours of a general anaesthetic or within 24 hours of a local anaesthetic.
It is aceptable to operate whilst taking non drowsy cold remedies such as Sudafed. Seek medical advice before operating whilst taking any other medication.

sect2.title: Disease and Immunisation
sect2.para: Crew who are operating overseas must satisfy any statutory requirement for vaccination and be able to produce a WHO approved "Certificate of Vaccination" if required.
Immunity after vaccination is not immediate and it will reduce with time. Approximate effectiviness is as follows:
Crew should not operate within 24 hours of receiving immunisation.
When operating in maleria infected countries, crew members are responsible for obtaining and applying appropriate medication.

sect2.title: Blood donation
sect2.para: Crew should not donate blood within 24 hours of a duty.

sect2.title: Diving
sect2.para: Crew should not fly within 48 hours of diving to a depth exceeding 10m. Crew should avoid any diving requiring the use of an aqua-lung within 24 hours of a duty.
Crew who have been treated for decompression sickness must not fly within 72 hours of recovery.

sect2.title: Surgery
sect2.para: Aeromedical advice should be sought before returning to duty following any surgical procedure.

sect2.title: Hypoxia
sect2.para: [Human Factors For Pilots, Green et al.]

sect2.title: Food poisoning
sect2.para: Crew who are operating together should not have the same meals. This includes crew food and eating together when downroute or on airport standby.
If food poisoning from crew food is suspected, a Food Safety Report form must be completed and medical tests carried out to identify the strain.

sect2.title: Definitions
sect2.para: Duty period: Any continuous period where a crew member is required to carry out a task associated with easyJet business.
Flight duty period: The period between reporting to operate a flight or series of flights and the on blocks time of the last sector operated.
Discretion event: The use of either commander's or individual's discretion to reduce a rest period, extend a duty period, ignore a cumulative limit or reduce a report time.

sect2.title: Required rest
sect2.para: For flight crew, the rest required before operating a duty is 12 hours or the length of the previous duty period, whichever is greater. For cabin crew, the rest required is one hour less than the flight crew.

sect3.title: Reducing required rest
sect3.para: These notes assume that a rest reduction is a single discretion event. There are additional limitations if the rest reduction is one of a series of discretion events.

At home base, flight crew may, at their discretion, reduce their required rest period by a maximum of one hour providing that the rest period is still at least 12 hours. Cabin crew may similarly reduce their rest providing the rest period is still at least 11 hours. All crew members must inform the commander at the start of a duty if individual discretion has been used to reduce rest.

When not at home base:
The commander may, at his discretion, reduce rest by an unlimited amount provided that at least 10 hours is spent in suitable accommodation.
Where a commander is not available, such as when a crew has split, individuals may, at their own discretion, also reduce rest by an unlimited amount provided that at least 10 hours are spent in suitable accommodation. The commander in charge of the subsequent duty period must be informed of this occurance prior to the first sector.
Where the preceding duty was less than 12 hours,easyJet may roster a reduction in rest equal to the amount that actual total accommodation transfer time was less than two hours, up to a maximum of one hour.

sect3.title: Increasing maximum flight duty
sect3.para: The commander may, at his discretion, increase the maximum flight duty detailed in by up to 2 hours. If required by a delay occuring during the turnaround before the final sector of a duty, the maximum flight duty may be extended by a further hour. Whenever this discretion is used it must be reported via the journey log. Where the discretion is greater than two hours a Discretion Report Form must also be competed to allow mandatory reporting to the CAA. There are additional conditions when exercising this discretion as part of a sequence of discretion events.

Where a flight duty is scheduled such that a rest period of between 3 and 10 consecutive hours may be taken between sectors, the company can increase the maximum flight duty by one half of that rest period. The allowance for inter-sector pre and post flight duties and the type of accommodation required are specified in EOM-A 7.1.13.

easyJet has also negotiated FTL exemptions that allow the maximum flight duty lengths in to be extended by either 30 minutes or 60 minutes at the planning stage. To utilise either of these exemptions a long list of conditions (detailed in EOM-A 7.1.12.9) must be met. Affected duties are annotated on rosters.

sect2.title: Minimum flight altitudes
sect2.para: MORA is defined as obstacle height+1000ft for obstacles up to 5000ft and obstacle height+2000ft for larger obstacles. Route MORA refers to obstacles within 10nm of a route centerline and end points and is depicted on charts below an airway with a lower case "a". Grid MORA refers to obstacles within the section of a chart outlined by the drawn latitude and longitude lines. Grid MORA should be used for planning.

When operating within 20nm of terrain with a maximum elevation >2000ft, the MORA should be increased to take account of wind speed using the following table:
MORA Wind Speed Correction
TerrainWind speed in Knots
Elevation0 - 3031 - 5051 -7070+
2,000-8,000ft500ft1,000ft1,500ft2,000ft
More than 8,000ft1,000ft1,500ft2,000ft2,500ft

When surface ambient temperatures are well below ISA, the following corrections should be applied to the wind corrected MORA:
MORA Temperature Correction
Surface Temperature Addition to MORA
ISA-16°C to ISA-30°C 10%
ISA-31°C to ISA-50°C 20%

An aircraft must not descend below the appropriate safety altitude unless it is following an approved Instrument Approach Procedure, is under positive radar control or is in continuous visual contact with all obstacles. Descent below safety altitude using an ILS as sole reference for vertical guidance should not be commenced until established on the localiser and within 10nm of touchdown.[Ezy-A 8.4.1]

sect2.title: One engine inoperative en-route net flight path
sect2.para: In the event of the loss of an engine at the most critical point along a route, and taking into account the effect of all relevant ice protection systems, the gradient of the net flight path must be positive at least 1,000ft above all obstacles within 5nm of the intended track. Furthermore, it must be possible to reach an airport where a landing can be made whilst clearing all obstacles within 5nm of the intended track by 2,000ft.

sect2.title: Usability of airports
sect2.para: easyJet is responsible for ensuring that all airports selected as destinations or alternates are adequate in all respects, including runway dimensions, obstacles, ATS, lighting, approach procedures, weather reporting and emergency services.

easyJet will categorise aerodromes from A to C in order of increasing difficulty. Operation to a category B aerodrome requires self-briefing from Ezy-C. Operation to a category C aerodrome requires a briefing and then a visit in an operating capactity or aerodrome specific training in an approved flight simulator.

Fire and Rescue category 6 is the normal minimum level. Category 5 may be accepted if the flight has been accepted and the flight crew are informed. Also, if a reduction to Category 5 is reported at the destination whilst airborne, it is acceptable to continue. In an emergency a landing may be made at an aerodrome with inadequate facilities where doing so is the least risk option.

listitem.para: A table for interpretation of TAFs with regards these requirements can be found in [Ezy-A 8.1.2]
Crossing runways may be considered independent if more than 6000ft is available on each before the intersection.

sect3.title: Cruise alternates
sect3.para: Cruise alternates must be within 365nm for the B737.

sect2.title: Aerodrome operating minima
sect2.para: All easyJet aircraft are Category C for the purpose of calculating operating minima.

Take-off minima are related to available lighting and are detailed in a table in [Ezy-A 8.4.2]. In general, if centre-line lighting, edge lighting and multiple RVRs are available, an RVR of 150m is required for take-off. With qualified crew this can be reduced to 125m with suitable high intensity lighting, LVPs in force and a 90m visual segment (6 centre line lights with standard 15m spacing) available. The Captain must be PF for any take-off where RVRs are below 400m.

Landing minima comprise an RVR requirement and a Decision Altitude (DA) for precision approaches or a Minimum Descent Altitude (MDA) for non-precision and circling approaches. The RVR requirement is a function of available lighting and DA or MDA. The DA or MDA is the greatest of Obstacle Clearance Altitude (OCA), system minima (see tables in [Ezy-A 8.1.3]), state minima and Aircraft Flight Manual limitations. Category II/III landing minima are provided at the front of the Jeppesen Text section. All other landing minima are on the plates for the specific airport.

An approach must not be continued beyond the outer marker or equivalent position (determined by DME, a suitable located NDB or VOR or a radar fix) unless the reported RVR is greater than minima. Where it is not possible to determine an equivalent position, 1000ft AAL may be used.

If RVRs are not available, the following table can be used to convert Met Vis to RVR for Cat I and non-precision landing minima only:
Met Visibility to RVR conversion for Cat I and non-precision landing minima

For any visual approach, the minimum RVR is 800m.

When circling is required, an absolute minimum of 600ft MDA and 2400m met vis is required. This may be increased by other factors, and specific minima are included on the relevant Jeppensen plate. If vertical guidance is not available for a circling approach, the following limitations also apply:
Day only Experienced Commanders only Captain PF if met vis<5km

A left-hand circling approach will normally be flown by the left seat pilot. A right-hand circling approach should be flown by the right seat pilot unless other factors override this. In marginal weather conditions, only one circling approach should be flown unless a significant improvement occurs. In general, a visual approach or a tailwind instrument approach is preferable to a circling approach.
Night operations require that at least runway edge. threshold and runway end lights must be on.

listitem.para: Fuel required for all phases from take-off at departure aerodrome to landing at destination aerodrome. It takes into account the longest probable SID and STAR with additional profile information included where applicable. The cruise section assumes optimum flight level and a fixed Mach of 0.78 for the -700 and 0.74 for the -300 (below FL 250 the -700 assumes 280kt and below FL210 the -300 assumes 300kt). A correction for aircraft burn degradation is also included.

Contingency fuel, being the greater of 5% of the trip fuel or 5 minutes MLW holding at 1500ft (182kg for -700, 211kg for 52888kg MLW -300 and 207kg for 51709kg MLW -300). It may be burnt at any time after engine start.

Fuel required to hold at 1500ft for 30 minutes. The calculation uses estimated landing weight at the alternate aerodrome. If it is determined that the fuel remaining on landing may be less than final reserve, a PAN call must be made. If it is determined that it will be less than final reserve, a MAYDAY call must be made.

Fuel for phases from engine start to line up. It is based on 11.3kg/min multiplied by statistical taxi times, and should be exceeded on only 15% of occassions. Fuel for 6 minutes APU usage is also included.
The sum of A to E

The maximum fuel that may be tankered without exceeding any of the structural limitations (a margin of 500kg is provided for MLW). If the figure is non-zero, it indicates that tankering would be preferable, but it must be manually amended to be the least of:
Fuel required for next sector + DEST + TAXY
4000kg + DEST + TAXY if fuel induced wing icing is anticipated
Maximum fuel taking into account take-off and landing performance
Maximum fuel to avoid breaking structural limitations in the event predicted ZFW or predicted fuel burn is inaccurate

FINAL RESERVE + ALT. This is the fuel that an aircraft must have at the point of go-around from the destination airfield in order to achieve a landing at the alternate with final reserve fuel. It is acceptable (and often safer) to plan to land with less than CMR at the destination if landing is assured.

sect3.title: Departure with less than CFP fuel
sect3.para: Fuel reduction below CFP for purely economic reasons should be limited to reducing taxy fuel where a short taxi out is anticipated and reduction of trip fuel by 4kg/nm where shorter SIDS and STARS are anticipated.

If payload is critical, a number of other adjustments are possible. The alternate fuel may be reduced if a closer suitable alternate is available, and may be replaced by 15 minutes holding fuel if a destination alternate is not required (see table in [Ezy-A Appendix 1 to section 8.1.7 to section 8.1.7.4] for the actual value for a given holding weight). It is also possible to slightly reduce contingency fuel requirements using either an en-route alternate aerodrome or the Decision Point Procedure (details are in [Ezy-A 8.1.7.5]).

note.para: Gender independent adult weight should only be used in exceptional circumstances.
An allowance for hand baggage is included. Any additional crew baggage must be taken into account.

sect3.title: Standard of entries
sect3.para: All entries must be completed in block capitals, and any signature must be followed by a printed surname, any applicable authorization or approval numbers and the date.
If an entry is made that is also the subject of an ASR, the descriptions should be the same on the two documents.
If an entry is changed, the incorrect entry must have a single line drawn through it, the reason for the alteration must be entered next to the original text and the alteration must be signed.

sect3.title: Layout
sect3.para: Each page is divided into a defect section and four tear-off sector record strips. The top half of each tear-off strip is for recording details of a sector that has just been completed. The bottom half of the strip is used to record pre-departure data.

With the exception of the Daily Check, engine starts and fuel used items, if anything has been entered in the defect column, a new page must be started for the next flown sector, and any remaining record strips must be crossed out.

Fuel figures should be recorded to the nearest 100kg. Where provided, the fuel uplift should be recorded corrected for temperature [Ezy-A 8.2.1]. Oil figures should be entered if they can be determined according to the manufacturer's recommendations, and should be crossed out if they cannot {find out the Boeing recommendations on this}. The "Oil Check" box is only applicable to engineering, and should be crossed out. Ground de-icing should be recorded or "nil" circled. If de-icing is done more than once, all the data on the current strip should be copied to the next strip, and the de-icing recorded there.

sect3.title: Removal of pages
sect3.para: The pink detachable sector record is removed after the Captain signs his acceptance, and routed to the maintenance organization. The whole pink page is removed if an entry has been made in the defect column (whether cleared by Engineering or application of the Acceptable Deferred Defects (ADD) procedures), or after scheduled maintenance. The yellow page is removed once all the sector strips have been removed or when the whole pink page is removed.

sect3.title: Defect deferral
sect3.para: When it is not possible to clear a defect prior to the next sector, providing that it is specified in the MEL as allowable or has been evaluated by an appropriately authorised engineer as not being an airworthiness item, it may be transferred to one of the ADD Pages. Unless there are maintenance actions specified, the commander may carry out this action.

If the defect does not affect airworthiness, it should be entered on the level 2 (blue) ADD sheet. Otherwise, it should be entered on the level 1 (pink) sheet. The complete tech log defect description should be transferred, along with the tech log page reference and item number, any MEL/CDL reference number and limiting criteria (e.g. expiry date). Once this is done, the MEL/CDL reference, the repair interval and the ADD reference can be entered in the "Action Taken" column and the defect can be signed off.
The ADD sheet should not be signed by the commander, but MOC must be informed so that it can be signed by engineering as soon as possible.

sect3.title: Cabin defect log
sect3.para: The SCCM enters details of cabin defects in the cabin defect log and presents it to the commander at the end of the flight. The commander must review the defects and transfer any airworthiness items to the technical log.

sect2.title: Fuelling procedures
sect2.para: The fuel supplier is responsible for ensuring that all fuel/ water checks are completed, that the bowser is properly earthed to the aircraft and that fuel caps are properly secured.

The commander (or suitable delegate) must ensure that fuel requirement is accurately communicated. When arriving on stand the fuel chart may be displayed once a clear evacuation route from the aircraft is established. The fuel requirement, including the requirement for each tank, must also be passed in person. If there is any possibility of confusion arising in verbal communications, a Fuel Data Card should be used.

The commander must also ensure that no smoking takes place within 15m of the aircraft, that strobe lights are not operated and that local restrictions are checked before starting the APU while fuelling.
PNF is responsible for monitoring the fuel gauges to ensure the correct amount of fuel is uplifted.

Refuelling may take place with passengers on board, but the following restrictions apply:
At least one pilot must be on the flight deck, and he must be in two way communication via intercom with the supervising ground crew.
No individual items of electrical equipment may be turned on or off.
Passengers must be informed that refuelling is taking place and instructed to have their seatbelts unfastened and told the toilets are out of use. The "No Smoking" sign should be on and the "Fasten Seatbelts" sign should be off.
Three cabin crew are required and they must be at boarding stations. The front door must be open with steps or airbridge attached. The rear door should ideally also be open with steps attached. If this is not possible, refuelling may still take place as long as the slide is serviceable, the refueller is informed and the cabin crew ensure the slide deployment area beneath the exit remains clear.
Local restrictions must be checked.

If ground transfer or defuelling is required, the fuel pump low pressure lights must be constantly monitored and the fuel pumps turned off at the first indication of low pressure. The fuel quantity in the tank that is being transferred from must not drop below 900kg. Ground transfer should not be used for de-icing.

sect3.title: Infants and children
sect3.para: Children under the age of 14 must be accompanied by a person aged 16 years or older.

Infants (children under two years) may fly free of charge if they sit on the lap of the accompanying person. A maximum of two infants is allowed per accompanying person. Infants under two weeks of age are not permitted to fly. Premature babies are not permitted to fly until six months post expected date.

The following restraints are acceptable:
Acceptable restraints for children
RestraintAge range
Infant extension seatbelt2 weeks to 2 years
Suitable car-type safety seat6 months to 3 years
Normal seatbelt2 years or more
A car seat is considered suitable if it has a rigid metal or plastic frams, is no wider than 42cm, has a four point harness and is upright and forward facing.
Under no circumstances must another passenger be asked to accept responsibility for an unaccompanied minor

sect3.title: Expectant mothers
sect3.para: Between 28 and 35 weeks (inclusive) of pregnancy, a medical certificate signed by a doctor (not a midwife) confirming pregnancy stage and fitness to fly is required. Passengers cannot be accepted for travel on or after week 36 of pregnancy.

sect3.title: Deportees
sect3.para: The Captain must be informed on all occasions when a deportee is carried. The passport and other travel documentation of the deportee should be retained in flight by the SCCM and handed over to the handling agent on arrival. The deportee must not be permitted to disembark at any point within the deporting territory unless escorted by a dispatcher or passenger handling staff. The deportee may disembark at a destination other than that in their ticket provided Immigration Authorities are contacted prior to arrival. For seating purposes, a deportee should be treated as "likely to impede evacuation".

sect3.title: Invalids
sect3.para: A passenger is considered an invalid when their physical, medical or mental condition requires individual attention which is not normally extended to other passengers. A list of conditions that will preclude carriage is included in [Ezy-A 8.2.2]. Invalids should be pre-boarded and seated as "likely to impede evacuation".

sect3.title: Live animals
sect3.para: The only permitted live animals are guide dogs, which may be carried on domestic flights only. The owner must have an Environmental Health Card, and the dog must be wearing the standard identifying jacket. A seat must be blocked off and the dog attached to it by a harness or lead.

sect3.title: Stowaways
sect3.para: If a stowaway is discovered, the company should be contacted and an entry made on the journey log. The Commander may request the authorities detain the stowaway pending charges.

sect2.title: Carriage of cargo
sect2.para: Wherever possible, cargo should be carried in a seperate hold to baggage. This is mandatory if there is any risk that cargo could contaminate baggage. Usually, cargo will be carried in the forward hold. It is the dispatcher's responsibility to ensure correct loading and that the cargo manifest matches the cargo carried. The cargo documents are the responsibility of the SCCM during flight, and they should be handed immediately on arrival to the dispatcher.

sect3.title: Human remains
sect3.para: Coffins may be carried if accompanied by a death certificate.

Ashes may be carried if accompanied by a death certificate and a certificate of cremation. They should be carried in a secure and appropriate container in the hand baggage of the passenger carrying them.

sect3.title: Musical instruments
sect3.para: Large musical instruments may be carried providing the passenger has purchased a seat for the instrument. A maximum of two instruments may be carried. An instrument must weigh less than 75kg and have a centre of mass less than 30cm above the seat cushion. It must be secured to a non-restricted window seat.

sect3.title: Aircraft spares
sect3.para: Aircraft spares that are not classified as dangerous goods may be carried on all routes except those to and from Switzerland. No flight crew paperwork is required beyond inclusion on the load sheet.

sect3.title: FDM Data
sect3.para: FDM data cards/ disks may be carried by hand. They are transported in blue padded zip sealed bags, and will already have been x-rayed before loading.
If the zip seal is broken or missing, the bag may still be carried if it is thoroughly searched. The broken seal should be reported to the FDM department.

sect3.title: Carriage of Royal Mail and British Forces Posted Overseas mail
sect3.para: Royal Mail may be carried either under the standard Post Office manifest documents (P2026 for domestic and CN38 or AV7 for international), or under the cargo handling agent's own manifests. Any mail manifest must show the weight and number of pieces of mail. Requirements for British Forces Posted Overseas mail are the same.

sect3.title: Secure Cargo
sect3.para: Secure cargo is MOD diplomatic/ classified material carried by a diplomatic courier. It is exempt from security screening, but is guaranteed to not contain problem items. The courier will oversee the ramp transfer of the cargo and the closure of the hold and will then board the aircraft, identify himself to the SCCM (who must check his ID) and sit in the seat nearest door 1L. On arrival, he will be first off the aircraft to be present when the hold is opened. The courier must be briefed of any diversions ASAP, and any support required should be provided.

sect3.title: Human Organs for Transplantation
sect3.para: These will arrive at the aircraft in a box sealed with tamper-proof tags. They are exempt security screening, but the police will have verified the origin of the consignment before accepting the delivery. The box should be carried in the flight deck under the Captain's supervision.

sect3.title: Types of fluid
sect3.para: ISO Type I fluid has a high glycol content and low viscosity. De-icing performance is good, but protection from freezing precipitaion is poor. It is best used for removing frozen deposits as part of a two stage process or when precipitation has stopped. Type I fluids are usually clear.

ISO Type II fluid includes a pseudo plastic thickening agent. This allows it to remain on the surface after application to provide protection from freezing precipitation. Shearing of the fluid allows it to flow off the critical surfaces as airspeed increases. Type II fluids are usually straw coloured.
ISO Type IV fluid is similar in operation to type II fluid, but uses more advanced thickening systems to give longer holdover times. Type IV fluids are usually green.

All fluids may be diluted with water. Required Type I fluid concentration is a function of OAT only, as dilution has a negligible effect on holdover. Required Type II and Type IV concentrations are a factor of OAT and holdover requirements. Tables are presented in [Ezy-A 8.2.4.6].

sect3.title: Precautions
sect3.para: De-icing fluid should not be used where it could cause loss of vision while being shed during the take-off roll.

A walk-round inspection should be completed by a qualified person after de-icing is completed. Flying and control surfaces should be clear of deposits, intake and drain holes should be clear of obstructions and a check should be made that de-icing fluid that has been diluted by the removed deposits has not refrozen on other parts of the aircraft. Undercarriage components should be checked for cleanliness and microswitches and uplocks should be checked for normal operation. If possible, compressors should be rotated by hand to ensure they have not frozen.
The flight crew should also move the control surfaces over their full range to ensure that they are free of obstruction.
Note that high winds or jet blast may cause damage to the de-icing fluid film and significantly shorten holdover times.

sect2.title: VFR/IFR policy
sect2.para: When controlled airspace exists between departure and destination airports, flights will be planned to remain within that airspace. Where controlled airspace does not exist, advisory airspace will be used if available. VFR flight should be considered exceptional.
Where a flight is planned to remain within controlled or advisory airspace, flight outside that airspace should only be considered for safety reasons.

sect2.title: Navigation policy
sect2.para: Basic RNAV equipment is mandatory throughout Europe. This requires minimum track keeping accuracy of +/- 5nm for 95% of the flight time (RNP-5). All EZY aircraft can meet this requirement, even with an inoperative DME (providing the remaining DME is auto tuning).

RNAV SIDs and STARs may be followed if they are in the FMC database. The use of BRNAV on published feeder routes into and out of terminal airspace is only permitted when above the relevant safety altitude.

sect2.title: RVSM
sect2.para: RVSM airspace is airspace above FL290 where only 1000ft vertical separation is maintained. All easyJet aircraft are RVSM approved.

When in RVSM airspace and within 1000ft of cleared flight level, vertical speed should not exceed 1500fpm. In addition, a check must be made passing FL200 that 1013 is set on all altimeters, and a check of the altimeters should be recorded on the CFP at least every hour and whenever a change of cruise level occurs.

The minimum equipment required for entering RVSM airspace is:
Two main altimeters with a difference in readings of less than 200ft and no failure flags
Two ADCs or two ADIRUs
Altitude alert system
At least one autopilot in CMD with either VNAV PATH or ALT HOLD annunciated.
If any item of equipment in the above list fails, ATC must be notified. If both main altimeters fail exit RVSM airspace.

If severe turbulence is encountered in RVSM airspace such that vertical navigation performance becomes unacceptable, ATC should be informed immediately so that either horizontal separation or increased vertical separation can be maintained. If the encounter is believed to be wake turbulence, paperwork should be submitted to Eurocontrol in addition to the normal ASR.

sect2.title: Altimeter setting procedures
sect2.para: Main altimeters should be checked during the pre-flight phase by setting both to airport QNH and checking that they are within 50ft of the airfield elevation and are within 50ft of each other. If planning a flight in RVSM airspace in a -300, the altimeters should be within 40ft of each other [33V Vol-1 Limitations]. If any doubt exists concerning altimeter accuracy, an expanded procedure using QFE checks is available in [Ezy-A 8.3.3].

Main altimeters should be set to QNH before take-off and then set to 1013 when first cleared to a flight level. The standby altimeter should be set to QNH for take-off, and then set to 1013 when passing MSA. In the descent, the main altimeters should be set to QNH when first cleared to an altitude and the standby altimeter should be set to QNH when passing FL200 or at TOD if cruising below FL200.

Pressure altimeters are subject to temperature errors, which may be corrected using the table in [Ezy-A 8.3.3 (once its updated!)]. When temperatures at aerodrome level are below zero, corrections should be applied to DA, CDA/MDA and SE acceleration altitude. In extremely cold conditions corrections should also be applied to MSA, procedure turn altitude, DME Arc and FAF [Level 1 NTC].

sect2.title: GPWS
sect2.para: [Ezy-A 8.3.5 and QRH NNM]

GPWS may generate either an "Alert" or a "Warning" depending on the situation. A "Warning" will use the phrase "Pull Up".{note: Ezy-A disagrees with QRH on "too low terrain"}. If flying in VMC with all obstacles clearly in sight or more than 5000ft above MORA, GPWS callouts may be disregarded. Otherwise, an immediate and positive response must be made to an alert, and the terrain avoidance maneuver should be flown in the event of a warning.
All alerts and warnings except "Glideslope" require an ASR.

sect2.title: TCAS
sect2.para: TCAS alerts are divided into Traffic Advisories (TA) and Resolution Advisories (RA).

A TA alerts the crew that a RA may be imminent. The response to a TA is a visual search concentrating on the area indicated. The flight path should only be changed if the visual search indicates a definite risk of collision.

If an RA is given, the manoeuvre indicated by TCAS must be flown, regardless of visual aquisition or ATC instructions to the contrary. ATC should be informed of the departure and, once adequate separation is acheived, of the return to the previously cleared level. RAs require an ASR to be filed.

sect2.title: In-flight fuel management
sect2.para: Flights of less than 20 minutes do not require a fuel check. Flights of less than one hour require a single fuel check, and flights of more than one hour require fuel checks at not more than hourly intervals. A fuel check should compare actual and planned consumption, check the remaining fuel is sufficient and determine expected fuel on arrival. The fuel total used should be the lower of the FMC totalized figure and the total from the fuel gauges.

If it is determined that fuel on landing at destination will be below CMR, action must be taken to reduce fuel burn. Options include flying at LRC or CI=0, changing levels or requesting shortcuts. If fuel burn cannot be reduced sufficiently to land with more than CMR, a decision must be made whether to divert or continue to destination. A decision to continue to destination is a committal to land there, and is permissable if landing is assured and the maximum anticipated delay is known. A landing is considered assured if no forecast weather deterioration or single failure of ground or airborne equipment can prevent landing. In general this means that Cat I minimas must be available at Cat III equipped aerodromes and non-precision minimas must be available at Cat I equipped aerodromes.

If it is determined that the fuel on landing may be less than final reserve, an emergency must be declared using a PAN call and ATC should be given an estimate of endurance. If it is determined that the fuel on landing will be less than final reserve, a MAYDAY call should be made.

sect2.title: Thunderstorms
sect2.para: Below FL200, any echo with sharp edges, strong intensities or strong gradients of intensity should be avoided by 5nm. If it has protrusions, it should be avoided by 10nm. Avoid all echos by 10nm, 15nm and 20nm above FL200, FL250 and FL300 respectively ((FL/10)-10).

If an area of thunderstorm activity cannot be avoided, set the aircraft up for turbulence, heavy icing and heavy precipitation. Turn up the cockpit lighting fully and lower the crew seats to prevent blindness from lightning flashes. Disregard the ADF. If the autopilot is making large trim adjustments it should be disengaged (although the yaw damper must remain). Manual flying should concentrate on maintaining constant trim, power, attitude and heading even at the expense of altitude maintenance.
If a thunderstorm is overhead or approaching prior to departure, delay the departure. If a thunderstorm is overhead or approaching at destination, hold clear and if necessary, divert.
If overflying a storm, it is recommended that at least 5000ft vertical clearance is maintained. Flight underneath a cb overhang is also hazardous as hail may be falling.

sect3.para:
The following time should elapse between the time a heavy aircraft in front becomes airborne and the time you become airborne when operating from the same runway or from parallel runways less than 760m apart.
Departure positionSeparation

sect3.title: Displaced landing thresholds
sect3.para: When a displaced landing threshold will cause the flight path of a landing heavy aircraft to cross your departure flight path, or will cause the departure flight path of a heavy aircraft to cross your landing flight path, 2 minutes must elapse between the times the aircraft are airborne.

sect3.title: Crossing projected flight paths
sect3.para:
If the flight path of an aircraft operating from a crossing, diverging or independent parallel runway (separated by more than 760m) crosses your projected flight path, the following distance should exist between the aircraft at the time of crossing:
TypeMin distanceTime equivalent
Heavy5nm3 mins
Medium or small3nm2 mins

sect3.title: Opposite direction
sect3.para: 2 minutes must elapse before take-off or landing when a heavy aircraft has made an opposite direction low or missed approach to the runway. 2 minutes must also elapse before a landing is made when a heavy aircraft has made an opposite direction low or missed approach on a parallel runway separated by less than 760m.

sect2.title: Admission to flight deck
sect2.para: Refreshments should only be brought into the flight deck when the flight time exceeds 1 hour and the aircraft in in the cruise phase.

Two cabin crew members must be positioned at the front of the cabin before the door is opened. One cabin crew member must stand at the front of the cabin facing the passengers at all times. The CCTV or door viewer must be checked before opening the flight deck door.
Passengers must never be allowed on the flight deck when engines are running.
A list of personnel that are authorised to use the jump seat is included in [Ezy-A 8.3.12].

sect2.title: Use of vacant crew seats
sect2.para: If insufficient passenger seats are available, with the specific authorisation of the duty pilot an easyJet staff member travelling as a passenger may occupy a vacant crew seat.

sect2.title: Incapacitation of crew members
sect2.para: It may be assumed that a crew member is incapacitated if he does not respond appropriately to two verbal communications or does not respond to a verbal communication associated with a significant deviation from a standard flight profile.

If the incapacitation occurs when the aircraft is on approach, fully configured, and visual with the runway, the landing should be completed. Otherwise, other crew should be summoned to care for the incapacitated crew member, an emergency should be declared and a diversion should be made to the nearest suitable airport. The incapacitated crew member must take no further part in the flight, even if he appears to have fully recovered. Medical advice should be sought by the remaining crew before further flying.

listitem.para: In the event of a failure, the pilot must take control. There will be no significant out of trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, but the landing cannot be completed automatically. When operating with RVR<300m, a go-around is assumed in the event of an autopilot failure below Decision Height.
An automatic landing may still be completed in the event of failure. Depending on the height when the failure occured, reversion to higher minimas or a go-around may be required.

If a failure occurs in a fail operational system and the aircraft is above alert height, either a go-around must be initiated or the approach should revert to higher minima. Once below alert height, the landing should be completed using the original minima.

Ground procedures invoked at suitably equipped airports when the cloud ceiling is 200ft or less and the RVR is 600m or less. They are designed to:
prevent the entry of ground vehicles and taxying aircraft into areas protected for take-off and landing
prevent the entry of ground vehicles and taxying aircraft into the ILS critical area, an area around the localiser and glide path antennas where the presence of metal objects would cause an unacceptable disturbance to the ILS signal
control access to the ILS sensitive area, a zone extending beyond the ILS critical area
regulate the flow of air traffic on the approach

sect3.title: Equipment failures during Cat II/III approaches

listitem.para: Deselect autothrottle and continue. PNF calls "25ft", at which point the throttles should be closed.
Revert to Cat-I minimas - neither automatic landing nor automatic go-around are available.
Both autopilots will disengage. Go-around and investigate.
Go-around for a persistent deviation above 200ft. Unless visually established, go-around for any deviation below 200ft.
Two generators (including APU generator) are required for an autoland. Generator failure may cause autopilot and/or autothrottle disconnect.
If RVR<300m, requires an immediate go-around.

varlistentry.term: Flare arms but does not engage

listitem.para: Disconnect and land manually if sufficient visual reference is available.
Go-around, advancingthrust manually. Automatic go-around will be available if dual autopilots are engaged.

sect2.title: Miscellaneous
sect2.para: If two consecutive approaches to an airfield have resulted in go-arounds, a third approach may not be made unless there has been a significant change in reported weather conditions.
An automatic landing should be made from a Cat II approach.

sect2.title: Missing manuals
sect2.para: If an easyJet manual is missing from the flight deck library, a replacement manual may be taken from a crew room. The yellow "Operations Manual Replacement Request" form at the front of the manual should be filled in immediately and faxed to Operations Support, and the journey log should be annotated with the discrepance and copied to NAV/PERF/OPS INFO.
If a chart or page is missing from a Jeppensen manual, the yellow Jeppensen comments sheet should be filled in, and the journey log suitably annotated.

sect2.title: Positioning crew
sect2.para: [Ezy-A 4.5]

Ramp transfer or remaining on aircraft for positioning is permissible if crew have arrived from a domestic flight. If crew have arrived from an international flight, crew must clear Immigration and Customs.

Flight crew, cabin crew and engineers may travel without a passenger booking as "extra crew" with the authorization of the duty pilot. If a gendec is required for the flight, anyone positioning as extra crew must be included.

sect2.title: Drunkenness on board
sect2.para: No person may embark if drunk. Passengers may not consume their own alcohol, and must not be served alcoholic beverages if it is suspected that they are drunk. If a passenger is refused carriage or a drink related incident occurs on board, an ASR must be raised and forwarded to the Quality Manager. Details of the items that should be included in the ASR are in Ezy-A.

sect2.title: Operation of doors from the outside
sect2.para: Cabin crew are not permitted to open or close doors from the outside. Flight crew may only open or close doors from the outside if an airbridge or ground steps are used.

sect2.title: Flight crew seats
sect2.para: Flight crew must remain in their seats except that one member of flight crew at at time may leave his assigned station for physiological reasons during the cruise phase. His seat must not be occupied by any other person during his absence.
Both pilots must wear full harnesses for take-off and landing and whenever the "Fasten Belts" signs are on.
